title: Subhash Chandra Agrawal vs Ministry Of Youth Affairs & Sports on 16 October, 2023

(Note: Proceedings in the matter are being pursued in pursuance of the
following interim decision dated 12.12.2022.)

Relevant facts emerging from appeal:

RTI application filed on          :   03/08/2022
CPIO replied on                   :   12/09/2022
First appeal filed on             :   15/09/2022
First Appellate Authority order   :   20/10/2022
2nd Appeal/Complaint dated        :   07/11/2022
                                        1
 "Upon perusal of the facts on record as well as on the basis of the proceedings
during the hearing, the Commission observes that the Appellant has raised his
discontentment with the reply provided by the Respondent with respect to point
no. 1, 2, 7 and 8 of the instant RTI Application and the Respondent vide his written
submission dated 25.11.2022 has apprised the bench that with respect to point
no. 7 of the RTI Application, no digital payments are made by Hockey India to any
vendor since all the payments are made through cheques/ bank electronic
channels, so the requirement to switch to digital payments do not arise and no
steps have been taken in this regard and with respect to point no. 8 of the RTI
Application, there is stay by the Hon'ble High Court of Delhi in W.P. (C) No. 11761
of 2018 vide order dated 02.11.2018 and that stay is still subsisting and the matter
is pending adjudication before the Hon'ble High Court of Delhi and the
Commission is convinced by the submissions made by the Respondent qua point
no. 7 and 8 of the instant RTI Application. However, with respect to information
sought in point no. 1 and 2 of the instant RTI Application, the Commission
observes that the Respondent has been changing stance as during the hearing, the
Respondent has submitted that the information sought is of commercial
confidence and the same pertains to personal information of third party which is
exempted from disclosure under Section 8 (1) (d) and (j) of the RTI Act and after
the conclusion of hearing, the Respondent vide his written submission dated
25.11.2022 has submitted that the CEO has given her dissent to share her personal
information but the said fact were never quoted by the Respondent during the
hearing. In the light of the aforesaid facts, the Commission considers it better to
adjourn the proceedings of the instant case by grating last and final opportunity
to both the parties to plead their case on the next date of hearing. Hence, the
Commission directs the Registry of this Bench to issue a fresh Notice of Hearing to
the parties concerned".

Information sought

:

The Appellant filed an RTI application dated 03.08.2022 seeking the following information:
"Please provide me information on under-mentioned aspects together with all related documents, file-notings, correspondence etc on under-mentioned aspects:
1. Complete information together with file-notings, correspondence, documents etc on appointment of Chief Executive Officer (CEO) at Hockey India mentioning name, nationality, monetary and other benefits available 2 to the CEO. Please also mention if any amount is paid to CEO in foreign currency or fund-transfer to some foreign bank-account.
2. Duties, responsibilities, powers, and other rights given to CEO at Hockey India also enclosing contract, agreement etc, if any, signed between CEO and Hockey India
3. Complete information on monthly or annual remuneration in any form paid by Hockey India other than to employees of Hockey India
4. Present updated list of employees together with their respective salaries and other benefits at Hockey India
5. Details of fund-transfer to foreign bank-accounts mentioning purpose and amount of each such fund-transfer (without names) in foreign bank- account in last three years
6. Details of cash-withdrawals from bank-accounts in last three years mentioning dates and respective amounts of cash-withdrawals
7. Complete information on steps taken by Hockey India to switch over to digital payment rather than cash payments at a time when even small vendors accept digital or payments through banks
8. Complete and detailed year-wise expenses on commission paid, if any, on sponsorships made by Hockey India ever since its inception in the year 2009 till date mentioning amounts paid to each of the person or body to whom such commission was paid in each of the year and for the sponsorship such commission was paid
9. Complete information on action taken to put information sought above on website of Hockey India
10. Any other related information.
11. File notings on movement of this RTI application."
3

The CPIO furnished a pointwise reply to the appellant on 12.09.2022 stating as under:

"1. The information sought is of commercial confidence and pertains to third party, hence the information sought cannot be provided under section 8 (1) (j) of the RTI Act, 2005 as salaries are considered personal information.

2. The information sought is of personal in nature hence the information sought cannot be provided under section 8 (1) (j) and (d) of the RTI Act, 2005.

3. No.

4. Attached as Annexure-I.

5. Attached as Annexure-II.

6. Attached as Annexure-III.

7. Payments are made through cheques/ bank electronic channels. No digital payments made by Hockey India to any vendor.

8. The information sought is of personal in nature hence the information sought cannot be provided under section 8 (1) (j) and (d) of the RTI Act, 2005.

9. Hockey India has already placed in public domain, the required information to be provided as suo-moto declaration under RTI Act on its website at below link:

https://www.hockeyindia.org/about/hi/accounts.

10. No information to provide.

11. No file notings."

Being dissatisfied, the appellant filed a First Appeal dated 15.09.2022. FAA's order, dated 20.10.2022, concurs with the reply of the CPIO, hence no further intervention required in the matter.

4

Feeling aggrieved and dissatisfied, the appellant approached the Commission with the instant Second Appeal.

Relevant Facts emerging during Hearing:

The following were present:-
Appellant: Personally present in the hearing.
Respondent: Vignesh Raj, Advocate along with Ranjit Gill, CPIO present in person.
The written submissions of the Respondent are taken on record.
The Appellant, during the hearing, reiterated the contents of his RTI application and instant appeal and submitted that the second appeal filed by him is only related to point nos. 1 and 2 of his RTI application. The Appellant contended that he has sought specific information on his RTI application on point nos. 1 and 2 but despite the fact the Respondent wrongly denied the same.
The Respondent, during the hearing, reiterated the contents of their written submissions, the relevant extracts are reproduced herein below:
"BASIS FOR NON-DISCLOSURE OF SUCH INFORMATION It is respectfully submitted the information sought in point nos. 1 and 2 is personal in nature, and is exempt from disclosure under Section 8(1)(i) of the RTI Act. Further, the information sought in point no. 2 is of commercial confidence containing 1. details of renumeration and terms of engagement of the CEO of Hockey India. The Respondent is exempt from disclosure such information under Section 8(1)(d) of the RTI Act. THE INFORMATION SOUGHT BY THE APPELLANT IS PERSONAL IN NATURE AND IS EXEMPT FROM DISCLOSURE UNDER SECTION 8(1)(D) OF THE RTI ACT J. It is respectfully submitted that the information sought in pt. nos. 1 and 2, including the CEO's salary and contractual details of her terms of employment, is personal information. Such information is exempted from disclosure under Section 8(1)(j) of the Act.
A 5 judge bench of the Supreme Court in Central Public Information Officer, Supreme Court of India vs. Subhash Chandra Agarwal (2020)5 SCC 481, while interpreting the term "personal information", has observed as follows: K. "292. it emerges from the discussion that certain category of information such as medical information, details of personal relations, employee records and professional income can be classified as personal information. The question of whether such 5 information must be disclosed has to be determined by the CPIO on a case-to-case basis, depending on the public interest demonstrated in favour of disclosure. L. As per the abovementioned judgement, the disclosure with regard to pay/salary of the CEO will undoubtedly fall within the scope of "personal information. Further, the Appellant has failed to disclose the public interest which is a mandatory requirement for disclosure of such confidential and personal information. Any disclosure of such personal information, in the absence of public interest, is violative of the right to privacy enshrined in Article 21 of the Constitution of India. M. Further, the legal proposition that salary is purely personal and confidential information and exempt from disclosure has been acknowledged in the draft Digital Personal Data Protection Bill, which was released by the Ministry of Electronics and Information Technology on November 18, 2022 for public comments. It has a provision which proposes to amend the Right to Information Act 2005. Clause 30(2) of the draft proposes an amendment to Section 8(1)) of the RTI Act, which will have the effect of totally exempting personal information from disclosure. "Clause 30 of the draft reads as follows- Clause (i) of sub-section (1) of section 8 of the Right to Information Act. 2005 shall be amended in the following manner: (a) The words "the disclosure of which has no relationship to any public activity or interest, or which would cause unwarranted invasion of the privacy of the individual unless the Central Public Information Officer or the State Public Information Officer or the appellate authority, as the case N. If these proposed amendments receive the Parliamentary approval, Section 8(1)() of the RTI Act would read as "information which relates to personal information". In other words, personal information will be totally exempt from disclosure. Further, the Supreme Court in Girish Ramchandra Deshpande v. Central Information Commr., (2013) 1 SCC 212, has observed that: 0. "13. The details disclosed by a person in his income tax returns are "personal information" which stand exempted from disclosure under clause 6) of Section 8(1) of the RTI Act, unless involves a larger public interest and the Central Public Information Officer or the State Public Information Officer or the appellate authority is satisfied that the larger public interest justifies the disclosure of such information." Therefore, the second appeal is wholly misconceived While such information can be disclosed voluntarily, it is submitted that the CEO is not willing to disclose such personal information to the general public. The CPIO had written an email to the CEO on 22.11.2022 seeking her approval for disclosing her salary details. The same was declined by the CEO vide email dated 23.11.2022. The email exchange between the CPIO and CEO is annexed herein and marked as Annexure-1 (Colly.). P. IS EXEMPT FROM DISCLOSING MATTERS OF COMMERCIAL CONFIDENCE AS SOUGHT UNDER SECTION 8(18) OF THE ACT THE RESPONDENT 6 Further, it is respectfully submitted that the CEO's contract is not only personal information but also a matter of commercial confidence which is exempt under Sections 8(1)(d) of the RTI Act. It is noteworthy to state that disclosure of employment contract and/or salary/benefits puts a person at a disadvantageous position insofar as negotiation of salary and /or other benefits jobs are concerned for a fresh job. Therefore, one is entitled to protect her personal information in law.
Xxxxxxxx PENDING PROCEEDINGS ON SIMILAR ISSUES BEFORE THE HON'BLE DELHI HIGH COURT It is submitted that a very similar RTI was filed with the hockey India on 13.09.2015 by an Applicant who sought disclosure of commercially sensitive information concerning sponsorship amounts received by Hockey India League as well as consultancy and legal expenses of lawyers engaged by Hockey India. The said information was denied by the then CPIO citing commercial confidence. The same was carried in appeal by the Applicant to this Hon'ble Commission which directed disclosure of the information. However, against the said Order dated 22.10.2018, the Respondent herein filed a Writ Petition before the Hon'ble Delhi High Court being WP (C) No. 11761/2018 wherein the Respondent challenged the findings of the Ld. Commission. Vide Order dated 02.11.2018, the Hon'ble Delhi High Court has stayed the Order of this Hon'ble Commission dated 22.10.2018.

The stay is still subsisting and the matter is listed before the Hon'ble Delhi High Court on 05.09.2023"

Decision:
The Commission, at the outset, observes that the Respondent taken the shelter that the present subject-matter in question is sub-judice before Hon'ble Delhi High Court wherein the Respondent challenged the findings of the Ld. Commission. Vide Order dated 02.11.2018, the Hon'ble Delhi High Court has stayed the Order of this Hon'ble Commission dated 22.10.2018. The stay is still subsisting and the matter is listed before the Hon'ble Delhi High Court on 05.09.2023.
However, the Commission in its earlier order dated 12.12.2022 has amply clarified that "stay is still subsisting and the matter is pending adjudication before the Hon'ble High Court of Delhi and the Commission is convinced by the submissions made by the Respondent qua point no. 7 and 8 of the instant RTI Application. However, with respect to information sought in point no. 1 and 2 of the instant RTI 7 Application, the Commission observes that the Respondent has been changing stance as during the hearing.......".

The Commission further observes from a perusal of records that the core contention raised by the Appellant in the instant Appeal was denial of information on point nos. 1 and 2 of the RTI application including name, nationality, monetary and other benefits available to the CEO. Please also mention if any amount is paid to CEO in foreign currency or fund-transfer to some foreign bank-account and Duties, responsibilities, powers, and other rights given to CEO at Hockey India also enclosing contract, agreement etc, if any, signed between CEO and Hockey India, etc. under Section 8(1)(j) of RTI Act.

In this regard, the Commission arrives at the conclusion that the CPIO has appropriately denied the personal information on point no. 1 of the RTI application regarding "Complete information together with file-notings, correspondence, documents etc on appointment of Chief Executive Officer (CEO) at Hockey India mentioning name, nationality, monetary and other benefits available to the CEO. Please also mention if any amount is paid to CEO in foreign currency or fund-transfer to some foreign bank-account" which stands exempted from disclosure under Section 8(1)(j) of RTI Act. The same can be garnered from a bare perusal of the text of Section 8(1)(j) of the RTI Act as under:

"8. Exemption from disclosure of information.--
(1) Notwithstanding anything contained in this Act, there shall be no obligation to give any citizen, xxxx
(j) information which relates to personal information the disclosure of which has no relationship to any public activity or interest, or which would cause unwarranted invasion of the privacy of the individual unless the Central Public Information Officer or the State Public Information Officer or the appellate authority, as the case may be, is satisfied that the larger public interest justifies the disclosure of such information;.."

In this regard, attention of the Appellant is also drawn towards a judgment of the Hon'ble Supreme Court of India in the matter of Central Public Information Officer, Supreme Court of India Vs. Subhash Chandra Agarwal in Civil Appeal No. 10044 of 2010 with Civil Appeal No. 10045 of 2010 and Civil Appeal No. 2683 of 2010 wherein the import of "personal information" envisaged under Section 8 8(1)(j) of RTI Act has been exemplified in the context of earlier ratios laid down by the same Court in the matter(s) of Canara Bank Vs. C.S. Shyam in Civil Appeal No.22 of 2009; Girish Ramchandra Deshpande vs. Central Information Commissioner & Ors., (2013) 1 SCC 212 and R.K. Jain vs. Union of India & Anr., (2013) 14 SCC 794.The following was thus held:

"59. Reading of the aforesaid judicial precedents, in our opinion, would indicate that personal records, including name, address, physical, mental and psychological status, marks obtained, grades and answer sheets, are all treated as personal information. Similarly, professional records, including qualification, performance, evaluation reports, ACRs, disciplinary proceedings, etc. are all personal information. Medical records, treatment, choice of medicine, list of hospitals and doctors visited, findings recorded, including that of the family members, information relating to assets, liabilities, income tax returns, details of investments, lending and borrowing, etc. are personal information. Such personal information is entitled to protection from unwarranted invasion of privacy and conditional access is available when stipulation of larger public interest is satisfied. This list is indicative and not exhaustive..."

With respect to point no. 2 of the RTI application, the Commission based on a perusal of the facts on record observes that as far as the information sought for in the RTI Application is concerned, in a strict sense, the Appellant has sought for a clarification to be provided by the CPIO and not "information" as envisaged under Section 2(f) of the RTI Act.

The Commission further observes that the information sought for in the RTI Application on point no. 2 does not conform to Section 2(f) of the RTI Act as it requires the CPIO to deduce and provide Yes or No answer as a form of confirmation of a speculative statement. The Appellant shall note that outstretching the interpretation of Section 2(f) of the RTI Act to include deductions and inferences to be drawn by the CPIO is unwarranted as it casts immense pressure on the CPIOs to ensure that they provide the correct deduction/inference to avoid being subject to penal provisions under the RTI Act. For the sake of clarity, the provision of Section 2(f) of the RTI Act is reproduced hereunder:

"2. Definitions.--In this Act, unless the context otherwise requires,--
9
(f) "information" means any material in any form, including records, documents, memos, e-mails, opinions, advices, press releases, circulars, orders, logbooks, contracts, reports, papers, samples, models, data material held in any electronic form and information relating to any private body which can be accessed by a public authority under any other law for the time being in force;.."

In this regard, the Appellant's attention is drawn towards a judgment of the Hon'ble Supreme Court on the scope and ambit of Section 2(f) of RTI Act in the matter of CBSE vs. Aditya Bandopadhyay & Ors.[CIVIL APPEAL NO.6454 of 2011]wherein it was held as under:

"35. At this juncture, it is necessary to clear some misconceptions about the RTI Act. The RTI Act provides access to all information that is available and existing.........A public authority is also not required to furnish information which require drawing of inferences and/or making of assumptions. It is also not required to provide `advice' or `opinion' to an applicant, nor required to obtain and furnish any `opinion' or `advice' to an applicant. The reference to `opinion' or `advice' in the definition of `information' in section 2(f) of the Act, only refers to such material available in the records of the public authority. Many public authorities have, as a public relation exercise, provide advice, guidance and opinion to the citizens. But that is purely voluntary and should not be confused with any obligation under the RTI Act." (Emphasis Supplied) Further for better understating of the scope and ambit of Section 2(f) of the RTI Act, reference may be had of Khanapuram Gandaiah vs Administrative Officer &Ors. [SLP (CIVIL) NO.34868 OF 2009], wherein the Hon'ble Supreme Court held as under:
"7....Public Information Officer is not supposed to have any material which is not before him; or any information he could have obtained under law. Under Section 6 of the RTI Act, an applicant is entitled to get only such information which can be accessed by the "public authority" under any other law for the time being in force. The answers sought by the petitioner in the application could not have been with the public authority nor could he have had access to this information and Respondent No. 4 was not obliged to give any reasons as to why he had taken such a decision in the matter which was before him...."

(Emphasis Supplied) 10 And, in the matter of Dr. Celsa Pinto, Ex-Officio Joint Secretary,(School Education) vs. The Goa State Information Commission [2008 (110) Bom L R 1238], the Hon'ble Bombay High Court held as under:

"..... In the first place, the Commission ought to have noticed that the Act confers on the citizen the right to information. Information has been defined by Section 2(f) as follows.
Section 2(f) -Information means any material in any form, including records, documents, memos e-mails, opinions, advices, press releases, circulars, orders, logbooks, contracts, reports, papers, samples, models, data material held in any electronic form and information relating to any private body which can be accessed by a public authority under any other law for the time being in force;
The definition cannot include within its fold answers to the question why which would be the same thing as asking the reason for a justification for a particular thing. The Public Information Authorities cannot expect to communicate to the citizen the reason why a certain thing was done or not done in the sense of a justification because the citizen makes a requisition about information. Justifications are matter within the domain of adjudicating authorities and cannot properly be classified as information." (Emphasis Supplied) Further, the information sought by the Appellant on point no. 2 of the RTI application regarding contract, agreement etc, if any, signed between CEO and Hockey India is a commercially sensitive information, which is exempted from disclosure under Section 8(1)(d) of the RTI Act.
Notwithstanding the foregoing observations, the Commission takes a liberal view in the matter on point no. 2 of the RTI application regarding "Duties, responsibilities, powers, and other rights given to CEO at Hockey India" , it is observed that it is a generic information which should have been also available in public domain and would also not affect the competitive position of the third party, therefore, in view of this, the Commission directs the Respondent to re-visit point no. 2 of the RTI application as mentioned supra and give revised reply/information to the Appellant free of cost, as per the documents readily 11 available in their records, within a period of 30 days from the date of receipt of this order under due intimation to the Commission.
No further intervention of the Commission is required in the matter.
The appeal is disposed of accordingly.
